title: 105_s2508
content:
The Act titled "Homebound Elderly Relief Opportunity Act of 1998" modifies home health services payment limits. The Act "Homebound Elderly Relief Opportunity Act of 1998" amends Section 1861(v)(1)(L) of the Social Security Act to set limits on home health services expenditures for fiscal years 1999-2002. The Act "Homebound Elderly Relief Opportunity Act of 1998" sets expenditure limits for home health services for fiscal years 1999-2002. The estimated expenditures for these years are $19.3 billion, $19 billion, $21.4 billion, and $23.1 billion respectively. The Secretary will consider past fiscal years' expenditures in determining if the applicable amount is exceeded. The Secretary must determine estimated aggregate expenditures by May 31 of each fiscal year. The Act "Homebound Elderly Relief Opportunity Act of 1998" sets expenditure limits for home health services for fiscal years 1999-2002. The Secretary will determine estimated aggregate expenditures for each fiscal year. The amendments made by the Act apply to cost reporting periods starting on or after October 1, 1998. Regionally uniform per beneficiary limits are established under the interim payment system. The Act "Homebound Elderly Relief Opportunity Act of 1998" sets expenditure limits for home health services for fiscal years 1999-2002. Regionally uniform per beneficiary limits are established under the interim payment system as follows:
- New England: $4,026.91
- Middle Atlantic: $3,796.19
- East North Central: $3,943.56
- West North Central: $3,911.64
- South Atlantic: $4,132.02
- East South Central: (details not provided) The Act "Homebound Elderly Relief Opportunity Act of 1998" establishes expenditure limits for home health services for fiscal years 1999-2002. Regionally uniform per beneficiary limits are set under the interim payment system for different census divisions and territories, ranging from $3,760.93 to $5,641.41. The Act "Homebound Elderly Relief Opportunity Act of 1998" sets expenditure limits for home health services for fiscal years 1999-2002, with per beneficiary limits ranging from $3,760.93 to $5,641.41. An amendment eliminates a special per beneficiary payment rule for new agencies, effective for cost reporting periods starting on or after October 1, 1998. The Act "Homebound Elderly Relief Opportunity Act of 1998" sets expenditure limits for home health services starting on October 1, 1998. Amendments include per visit cost limits and judicial review provisions. The Homebound Elderly Relief Opportunity Act of 1998 establishes expenditure limits for home health services starting on October 1, 1998. It includes amendments regarding per visit cost limits and provisions for administrative or judicial review. The Homebound Elderly Relief Opportunity Act of 1998 sets expenditure limits for home health services from October 1, 1998, including amendments to per visit cost limits and administrative or judicial review provisions. Section 4603(e) of the Balanced Budget Act of 1997 is amended to eliminate mandatory reduction in payment limits. SEC. 3. REPORTS ON INTERIM PAYMENT SYSTEM. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress by January 1, 1999, detailing research on a prospective payment system for home health services under Medicare. The report should also include the implementation schedule for the system. Additionally, within 60 days of the report submission, MedPAC will review the Secretary's report. The Medicare Payment Advisory Commission will submit a report to Congress analyzing the Secretary's report on home health services payments under Medicare. The report will include recommendations on any impediments to access to these services. Additionally, GAO audits will be conducted. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct audits on research expenditures by the Health Care Financing Administration and estimates of aggregate spending for Medicare home health services for fiscal years 1999 through 2002.
